interpretation.p: All digital surrogates of the original source are linked with the markup textfile.
All Gaelic (and English) texts have an English summary, index terms, keywords, and, where applicable, a taxonomic reference.
For some Gaelic (and English) texts a bibliographic reference(s) will be provided to other sources.

correction.p: Errors from the original source transcription have been kept to a minimum by employing stringent quality control procedures. In addition, all texts have been proof‐read by the text editors.

A guiding principle of the Alexander Carmichael notebooks markup procedure is to approximate the original document as closely as possible, so that the character of Carmichael's transcriptions is preserved along with its content. XML (eXtensible Markup Language), with its capacity to convey emendations such as deletions (crossed out) and supralinear additions and so forth, can digitally reproduce an authentic version which reflects the source documents.
Where authorial changes, e.g. substitution, have occurred in the text then this has been annotated.
Where there are errors they have been corrected and words which were difficulty to decipher has been indicated

In such cases missing words or letters have been supplied. Quotation marks and other missing grammatical marks have in the main not been supplied. Where there are gaps in the text usually because the word was inaudible (some background noise, perhaps) or where the transcriber could not make out what was being said in the act of transcription (perhaps the speaker was inarticulate or mumbling or for whatever reason) then these have been tagged, though not explained; where a word is now difficult, illegible or just unclear, then this has also been tagged.
All such changes have been annotated in accordance with TEI 5 procedures.

normalization.p: No normalization of the words such as changing the source text to conform with current Gaelic orthographic conventions has been undertaken. The texts are as given with only minor editorial changes. in order to preserve the integrity of the original texts.

quotation.p: All opening quotation marks, hyphens, dashes, apostrophes, periods, colons, etc. have been retained in the source text and have been encoded in accodance with ISO entity references, etc.
All double marks have been processed using straight quotation marks, that is, ". All single quotation marks have been rendered using apostrophe.

hyphenation.p: End‐of‐line hyphenation has been retained. All unambiguous end‐of‐line hyphens have been retained, and the trailing part of a word has not been joined to the preceding line.of‐line hyphenation has been retained. All unambiguous end‐of‐line hyphens have been retained, and the trailing part of a word has not been joined to the preceding line.

segmentation.p: Folio numbers have been added in pencil at the top of each notebook page are retained using the pb (pagebreak) element together with the n attribute for the page number and the ed attribute to specify the edition.
When an tale‐text or song which, more often than not, fills more than one page, it is segmented with page break.

langUsage.language: Approximately 40% of the fieldnote and transcription bokos are Scottish Gaelic, and the remaining 60% consist of English or Scots, along with stray quotations in Latin.

change.item: Proof-read and made corrections to file.

div.p:
Rev MacDonMacDonald said the caves were
mom.monuments of folly. I doubt if were not rasraised
as gtgreat mo.monuments of folly every day. No so visvisible said he
See CapCaptain Thomas remark abtabout laziness
of peoppeople to investinvesting in his work of the Outer
Hebrides. From this branch
The farmer looks up the grass sin
as foods for his cattle he sees no beauty
in its leaves no art in its structstructure – no
adaptadaptation in all. He sees not that benbeneath
is combcombed with rills - - -
nor that 'Ilka blade o grass has it's anain drap o dew
The mariner sees nothing in the gildgilded
skye but a star to provide him on his
course & a moon to light him to his house
He sees not the comet speaking
Nor orbs that shew the milky way
nor hears "the music of the
spheres for ever singing as they shine"
He prayeth best who loveth best.
Both things great & small
For tis the great God who loveth us
Has memade & loveth them all.

Clann ic Leoid ic Thorcuil
16 18 under the stone at Aoi. The last
was Calum MacLeoid mac Thor.Thorcuill
ic Leoid small crofter. He was
the heir of the MacLeods. Iain
Garbh killed 16 in taigh Iain Wylie
in Stornoway. This old mans great
great grandmother held the candle
to him while this was done. She was
but a little girl – Catriona nighean
Sheorais. Iain Garbh made a com
pact with a Gobha that he wodwould
assist him, which the Smith did
not fulfil – Gobha DuDubh Thonga.
IIain GGarbh met him and ubraidubraided him
for his cowardice. The Smith prepreferred
to be buridburied alive rather than be
killed outright. I.Iain GGarbh did this and
IIain GGarbh was walking over his grave
while the latter was still alive.
Se duin ro bhriabhriagh bh ann
Torcuil oighre – Torcul
oighre nan gruaigruaidhean grios -gris –
neach. This was the first
of the Lews MacLeods in
Mealabost.

A Eaglais na h-Aoi is the
oldest church in Lews also the
buryburying: place – St ColumbColumba. John
Wylie built one of those who came
here from Fife. The left house pro
in Stornoway.

Do Mhurachaidh mear mac Mhic LeodLeoid
Bha thusthusa an Leodhas fo thuathuath
S bha mise thusathaobhsa an StraStrath leoid ud

div.p:
Cragan = a Lews patera, Suileag Cragan
a smaller patera Croc =

AonasAonghas Mac Aulay, Croc
na h-Aoi. aged 82. Aug.August 29 681868.

The Mac Aulays had Lews
first. The Mac Aulays and
Morrisons were always at feud. They
used to have creachs.

Cnagan agus {Suileag {suileag Sgeip a thing
for souring cream. Bought from John
MacLeod, Paible. Cnagain are made
of Clay beat with a stick till the clay
is tough and consistent. It is then built
up layer by layer like planking a boat.

Taigh uairich small house at end
to keep fishing and lines tackle.

DonDonald MMac Phie Gobha Breuvaig (Bre
bhai bhig name of old) Friday 21 1869

An Carra Bhoradh. There was a
hole throthrough 1 in diadiameter. L.Length. 8½ FFeet BBreadth 2 FFeet. This stone
was used of old as a brangas. There was
a hole throthrough and and iron throthrough this for
going round the neck of delinquents
The last woman put in the
brangas was Mairi Thaillear
(Nic an t-Saoir) Allasdale
Put in for stealing a sheep. Her
brother who was Cleireach an t
Sagairt. He was paspassing and while
his sister was in the irons said
to her, Ga fuar am bior a Mhairi
so te a Mhairi is teteotha an coire
(am bior roslairoslaidh). Patra Taillear.
This woman had an only son
diolain and MacNeill took
him away to the army and he was
killed in Egypt under AbercromAbercrombie

Carra Bhurraig. Na h-Aodain arda
was the name of the carradghscarraghs of old

div.p:
Composed by a aunt of MacLeod
of Harris to MacNeill Dhun an t-Sleibh
her husband. She alleged that the Priest
attempted to take advantage of her in the
confessional (He was Irish.) The
Priest drowned a candle in chapel on
the Sunday follingfollowing indicating that she was
ex-comex-communicated. This angered MacNeill
and led to a quarrel between himself
and wife. She left and went home to
her father. She fell with a former
sweetheart. She then compcomposed this
song upon hearghearing which MacNillMacNeill
said Co sam bi leis an leis
an long luchd s liomsa a clar clar and went
with his biorlain for her. MacNillMacNeill
then left the Church of Rome. There
was a ban against Cath.Catholics during
the CarrasCarghas and fad na h-aidolein
not to make balls. To spite the Priest
Mac Mhic Neill Dhun an t Sleibh
make to balls and feills. He was ex-
comex-communicated. In going out of church he
said to the Priest that he would never
hear Mass again and so left the
Church of Rome. This was the
Lady MacNiellMacNeill who left Cios-
mal. All rent was paid in kind
in those days. She then went to Lag
fhliodh from which the woman
came with the prestpriest by the Lag fhliodh
close to Doirlin at Tangasdal.
Stiom, Siaman a bhios eir bial plàt

div.title: An Fhideag Airgid

lg.l: Co sheineassheinneas an fhideag airgid
Hi uill uill o
Mac mo righs eir tintighinna dh Alba
O ro hu o huill o.
Air luing a bhar mharaiche ghreanan
Ho ro hu o hu ill o
Ribean an t sidasioda Fhrangach
Ullagan oir eir g gach ceann diu
Mo ghaol a minister ainmeil
Cha b e mac sin Mr Fearachar
Cha b e ogha Mairi Simason
Ga b e thriallathriallas gu taitaigh talla

The Dall Mor told DonDonald MacPhie
that the song was composed to Prince
Charlie.

Mor mac ninnighean Iain ic DhonilDhomhnuill
bhain

div.p:
One Peter Campbell from Barra
went to Loch nan UaghUamh for timber. Food
was scarce in Barra – no grain but
plenty of butter cheese & flesh. They
landed a pot in a nook to boil beef
when they saw a large vessel come BBook 2 ppage
TransTranscribed 17 June 691869
AAlexander AArchibald CCarmichael
ashore in the Loch. He sent a boat
ashore. A gentleman landed
from the boat under whose arms
two men went & took him out dry
They asked P.Peter Campbell to take
ashore arms swords & guns. He did
so and they hid them. He was asked
what pay he charged. He told them
that if they had grain food he prefpreferred. The
boat was loaded with flour & biscuits
till he told them that they would sink
his boat. He came home to Barra
and the pot is still in Lochnanua.
This was the landing of P.Prince Charlie.

Mac a' Chreachaire. faiseacfaisneachd
Chlann Neill. Was a poor man who lived in
Ciosmal castle with MacNeill. He got his
faisneacfaisneachd in a slineinslinnein muilt where he
read it. Was never marrmarried. Had no friends
here. Was telling anything that was to happen.
Among other that Ciosmal uair'eachuaibhreach
nan cuach would yet be a garraigarraidh bhiasta dughadubha
fo nead nam feannag. This was so. A hoodie had nestnested when there 18-
MacNill was insulted & he ord.ordered him to be put
into a siarachsia-ramhach and sent off to Maol-
donaich and never to show face. Here
he lived & died. The totatobhta he had & the plot
he cultcultivated are still seen. Place called
Goirtean Mhic a Chreachair. Said
RuaraiRuaraidh nan seacseachd RuaraiRuaraidh sann
ra linn a thig a fu'asfuthas. S minig
a bhios thig ann ri linn agus is
meinig a nach bi ann ra linn.
FalbhaiFalbhaidh a chuile duine am
BarraiBarraidh fhastfhathast thar gob an aon
RuRubha. Be so gob na h-Airde glaise
An am goirt a bhuntata the people
left Barra here when they all under
stood the allusion. He predpredicted that Barra
would yet be all under geoigeoidh ghlasa
and that the dara duin uasal wldwould
be fo'n duin uasal eile sosa pholl a
gearadh na moine – so scarce
would the people become.
RuaraiRuaraidh nan seacseachd Rua.Ruaraidh.
mac na baintearna baine.

TiarnTighearna is measa thig no thainig
S meinig &c. CailliCaillidh e BarBarraidh agus
an treăbh uile. GheoGheobh sliocsliochd an ama-
dain ris an omhsichoinsich a ristrithist i.
Be so Fear Bhreuvaig (RuaraiRuaraidh
mac Gilleonain (mac do Ghilleon
an mor ririgh nan gaisgeach) Bi an
omhseachoinseach, bean an fhir so. Sann
as a Mhor'thir thainig i. Bha easan
agus ise faoin diudiubh fhein. ChaiChaidh
iad so do dh-America agus than
an sliocsliochd lan beartais san duaichduthaich
sin. Be am fior oighre dlieachdligheach
Gilleonain so ach a chionn e bhibhith
faoin thug athair an oireacoighreachd do
RuairiRuairidh Breac agus 's e SliocSliochd RuairiRuairidh
Bhric a chaill a BarraiBarraidh. That
letters would be sent all over the world
to invite the seann treăbh back to BarBarra.
That Maor nam meoir mora agus
dall nan 24 meori fichead agus gun
tigtigeadh am Muilleir a bhi a blébleith leis a
char chearr. The car cearr goes in
the prepresent millstones against the sun.

The MacNeills had a M.S.Manuscript of Mac
a Chreachaires faisneacfaisneachd. The late
Col.Colonel MacNeill told a man that he had
a MSManuscript of this. Ach fagfagaidh mise briagach
e. Tha e graiag raidh gun caill mise BarraBarraidh
ach muma chaill gheogheobh mi ristrithist i.

Mor ni Dhiarmaid ic Sheathain
ic DhunnachaiDhunnachaidh ic Earraghoil mairmathair
DhonilDhomhnaill Eoin am BearnariBearnaraidh. Be SeathSeathain
so gan d rinneadh A SheathSheathain sa SheathSheathain
Toradh coirc Earraghoil toradh coirc Eara'ailEarraghoil
chulasa so ann an creaig aig taitaigh
chlach. Bha i so eir toirt an toraidh
as a choirc.

Loch Lì on top of Beinn mhor.
A small lòn or lakelet in which the
strubain grow (cockles). The are very
small but alive as if only embryos.
Don.Donald MacPhi saw these often often

Gath – a pole, for mast or oar.
and wondered much at them.
They were most perfect in form but
he never saw any on TraiTraigh mhor so
very small – none large. The Dall
told him that he saw a plant growing
on close to Loch li and if a horse
trampled upon it thothough only after the
shoes being put on by the best smith
he wothey would fall off. Had no
name for the plant.

div.p: Miulay Saturday 22, 1869 Ruairi M mac DhonilDhomhnuill 94 years

A sister saw her dead sister in her
sleep at night and she came and sang this
cumha to her. This was an Ais-
lig she saw. Twas in Ireland.

div.p:
Sunday May 23 1869 Left Miula at
12 NNoon. Came to Fala-mhuilt, where the
people tied & hid their fat wedders from Mac
Neil It a ledge. The sea washed them all
away & drowned. The last Col.Colonel took
away the cattle of the people after he
was becoming bankrup.bankrupt althoalthough not in
his debt.

Carraig Cillemhicheil
is a little SSouth of this. Carraig a fishing
rock here. Creag a precip.precipice. Bile-
bìbis a fishing rock. Carraig, ununder the
small white shell fish on the rocks. RuRubha
nan carrag. Ru-eoiridhRubha-eoiridh. Sloc-threum
threumisgeir. A gully 120 ftfeet high where
they hoist seaweed. Se'igeir, Sloc bheig
eir, a cave going in some distance where
pigeons breed. Fauay hill grey & rocky & full
of old dykes. Sumhsabaist Totaichen
Shuinsabaist. Leacach. Heacal.
bheag above this & then Heacal mhor
on top of hill oppopposite the landing place in
in BearnBearneray. Carnan is the highest
Cladh-Neart the highest bit on Carn
an. Coir-fhiarail is the finest place
in Min.Mingulay. Glaic nam basdairean the
top of this. There is a fine echo from
this glen from a partiparticular spot in Bearn.Bearneray
Am Bo carrach. From this rock
the sea div.divides. On one side the tide runs
one way & vice versa, Leac Ia'uin, A
fine ledge and the rock above stands upupon
pillars. Gǐ'a'rum bheag & Giarum mhor
on other side. Tide in velocity. Smart
breeze right after & hardly able to stem it. Had
to put on the oars besides. Neap tide Spin
aker to stem it. RuRubha lialiath Ghi innis
the rock in layers like cylopeancyclopean mas
onry. An Dùn almost cut off frfrom rest. Here
a long numnumber of fortificationfortifications. Catarnisseiy the
rock on this side of the Dun. The Dui
eanach fight & allow the people to take
them & even aftafter they are taken into the boat
fight. He goes as fast under as above
water & with the wing & feet. The LaigLamhaidh
is brown and black & long in the bill.

Ruairy an Ruma kildkilled standing on one ledge 8
score & 14 & birds laiglamhaidhean & Duidubh-eunaich & 300 eggs. 20
score & 12 score he stearnadh one day. The dog
assisted & would leap up while they were flyflying.
He lost 18 dogs with the rocks.

Iain mac FhFhearchair ic MMhurchaidh was an uncluncle of Rury.
He was a son his grdmothgrandmother had before heshe marmarried
his grdfathgrandfather. Capt Scott was the offrofficer who hangdhanged
Iain. 600 soldiers were in BearnBearneray & Miulay
for a week. The ship left their parparties for that time.
Not a living creacreature was left in these
isles by them. BlianaBliadhna nan Sasun
ach was this year caldcalled. The peopeople fled to the rock.
Two men came under night to the baile to see how
things stood. They put a hook down the fair
leas & took away some beef the SasunSasunnaich
had on the fire. Ho Chatrina ni Lach Fhionaghal

The LangaiLangaidh has eggs but not the DuiDubh-eunach. An
Lòran, the bird in the shell (frfrom Lŏthar). 20 yrsyears

The Seigire or Kittie-wake's nest is often wash
ed away. It makes it on the face of the rock with mud.

The Each uisg took away a girl fr.from the house
on a Sunday. He put his head on her
knee. She cut her apron. He came
the next SunSunday an riocriochd lasgaire sgiamh
ach og. She fdfound the lafogach in his
hair. He cardcarried her up Creagan-oillt.
TheThey saw them up Glaic an da bheann
and they aft.afterwards fdfound her sgamhan floating on
Lon-greann at Clach an Eich uisge.
There is a greann upon this lakelet
every day in the year. Only a pool round the
boulder.

div.p:
Comp.Composed to a girl who was in the hill look
ing for sheep & met with a leanleannan sisith who
was for keeping her in his own bruth
sith. Curious to hear the bra late on
Saturday & Monday morg.morning early to pre-
pare the morgmorning meal. Walks on top
of the house. The peoppeople make them a comcommon
road & work there at wool & spring and caird
ing with troops of children about them.

div.title: Mac Iain ic Sheumais
div.p:
Her father who was a great or great great
grdsongrandson of DonulDomhnull Mac IIain ic SheSheumais was called
after him. Mac IIain ic Sheumais was sent
to EiriscaiEiriscaidh to be out of the way. In bring?
grandsons ic While & when he doesn't

DonDonald put his sword in the scabbard caught by this
point and drew it down with all his might upon
the head of Macleod. He but down alaban a chum
his sgull upon his brain & Macleod began sing-
ing went mad & walked into a lake near by and
was drowned. The man who insulted DonDonald seeing
the result of his stratagem ran off fearing DonDonald's
vengeance & was never heard of again DonDonald
brotbrought home all his men He & his men returdreturned to Mac
DonMacDonald in triumph the women old men and
children turning out and singing a song
of triumph before them. DonDonald handed the famfamous
sword to MacDonald who drew it from the scabbard
Ud ud Don. The sword was of blood & gore
Ud ud DonDonald you have not cleaned the glave ere
handing it back to me. Now said DonDonald I have stained
it to the best of my ability – be thou cleansing it
to the best of yours.

that he saw moran sluaisluaigh lucluchd e achai
landing upon Uist and fearg that ravage
were burying conntcontinued. He started up crossed
caolas cnap and walkwalked down throthrough Uist
When he met a gaisggaisgeach he said Bha
lalatha foghraifoghraidh aig am ort – lean mi. Then
he had a little number of warriors
in his train when he reachreached Carnish
Angus Maclellan never heard that
he had lairds in serservice. After he was
woundwounded. He was taken to Caisteal Bhurgh
and Mac Ic AileanAilein either DoulDomhnull Mor
son of Iain Muideartach or
sent for a doctor. The arrow in the ad was
barbed and diffdifficult to withdraw. The leigh suc.succeeded
There was an old woman in the house
who was sent to nurse DonldDonald. She was a
Leodach & had no love for him. She was
sucking some drink for him and while
cooling it she would take it and then
eologuise saying – O bhi sa aonach
chan fhumain uthu so. She then wdwould take

Donald met the Macleods on Sliabh a
Chuillin. A place on the north side of
one of the Cuilinn hills. The place is a five
miles from Carbost on the road side only a mile
or two from RuRubha an dunain bhuibhuidh savage
was battle put at a spot known as Blar na
Creiche DonDonald conquered and by his own fierce valour
inspired his men the same. On the way to
meet the MacLMacLeods. DonDonald presentpresented such an uncouth striplgstripling
app that he overoverheard one of his men say to others Se thug
eir an ludarneach phiollogach phealleagach
bhalaich so bonnach mor eorna s cuil am bruich
eadh e sidsiod. DonDonald was fired at the insult but purefrain
from a remark till they were returning in triumph after
the battle. He then went up to this man & have prove
mysmyself of a balach now said he? No said the other you have
proven yourself a man. But see you not yon one.
in the nook. DonDonald looked round and saw MacDhonuilMacDhomhnuill ghlais
na DraonichDraoinich hiding himself beneath the bank of a
stream. DonDonald was at him. MacLeod was cloaclothed in
armour and was likely to see the best of it.

returned to take claiclaidheamh an tolaidh. It was then
that he MacDonald sent for his nephew DonlDonald
who was a raw young of 16 or 17. DonDonald now
must take the claiclaidheamh an tolaidh and lead the clan
on to battle. MacLeod is threatening to deprive me
of some of my land and you must defend
fearann an tolaidh from any aggression. Am
fear gam bi feum an fhearainn sin ought
to take the family glaive and not me. If he would
have done that poor Donald would not have
been offered it. But since he is such a degenerate
son of his father none must show the clan & the
world that you are not. So here I hand you the
family glaive. Go forth with it to conquer and
bring it home unsuckled & DonDonald rushed forth to battle
at the head of the clan and not having begun much
accustomed to a ceanadach forgot in his hurry to
take one so that one had to be often times

div.title: Mac Mhuirich Mor
div.p:
ChaiChaidh e mach an bheinn a dheanudheanamh
radrathad dhana beo'aicheanbeothaichean gun
Eilean a Churaig. Nuair a raingrainig
ae bha n tuisg ard s chan fhai.fhaigheadh e
chun an eileaneilein. Chuir eir cloich
agus thug e suil agus de chunnchunna
e ach creatair beag {biatach biteach –
mar phiseag chait mo chom
Thug e dhachdhachaidh cuilean na
biata moire. Gu de nan creatcreatair
tha ta agad a sin deir a bhean
no boir.boireannach mor coin briabriagh. An ta
tha creacreatair a fhuair mi fo sgasgath creag
An ta cuir a mach cuir a mach
e gu h-ealamh – se chuir an
cath mas cheann. Fag.Fagaidh mi an
trast e gach ceannard a dheandheanamh
dhomh. O is beag tha fhios agdagad
gu de thainig nad luib. ChaiChaidh chuir
e beo. ChunChunnacas a sin a bhiast a tintighinn
agus thainig e chun an dorust
agus dh' iarr i a cuilcuilean a chur
a mach no cath us coraigcomhraig a thoirt chumail
di ri. Cuir thugam a mach
mo chuil.chuilean caoin caidreach
Ana spog spardrichspaidrich.

Cuir thug.thugam ors a bhean agus
faigh iarrtas nach uraurra dhidhith dhean.dheanamh
Dean clachan Lainginis
ThoisThoisich i agus rinn i an clachan. Cuir
tuille ard eir ors ea eise. Rinn i so.
Dhiarr i so a n cuilcuilean a chur a
mach eirno cath us coragcomhrag a chum
ail ri. Tarruind Thoir dhachdhachaidh
a dhomh chruach mhoine mhor a Laing
inis. Chan urra mi u s ur. Tha
da chliachliabh mhor mhoin' agam fhein as

mhoine. Thoir dhomh nis mo
chuilchuilean no cuir run cath us
coragcomhrag. Cha toir gus an tubhtugh a

gun ceann so thaothaobh gu taobh le
te itean ian a gheogheobh i sa chea

anach gorm. Rinn i so. Thoir

ors a bhean rud nach urra dhi dheandheanamh

Going 3 times southwise of the cla
cladh made a mare retain her foal,
and this was done to all the mares in
Uist. Bha tearmad aig Clann
Mhuirich. When a person reachreached
Clachan Staoligearry he was safe.

div.title: Faire Chlaidh
div.p:
Bha Cleireach Hough a fairfaire
chlaichlaidh. Bha e faicfaicinn rud neonach
a chuile oichoidhche nach rorobh cordacordadh
ris – creatair beag donnag og
nuirenuair bha iad a bualadh uapa
na h upagan. ChaiChaidh e gu seanseann
duine bha eir a bhaile & Feuch
ars an sseann duine de am faifaigh uthu taradh
oroirre agus buibuin ririthe. Bhi e sin ri
Co an creacreatair beag bocbochd usa gad up-
agadh ris an so bho choluncholunn gu
coluncholunn. Tha mis te thuirt mi nach
eir deideigh mo mhàrmhàthar ann an Caolas
agus mi ruiruith chaorach cuidcuide ririthe.
Cuir usathusa mo chnamhchnamhan ann
agus ins.innsidh mi fhefhein duitdhuit far a
bheil iad cuir ann am bogsa beag ud
agus cuir a mach eir bun fathail
Hoŭgh e adiad agus chan fhaic sinn
tuilltuille i. RuigRuigidh mi mo chuidchuideachd fhein.
Cha do cheancheannaicheadh leac a so domhdhomh
agus sin an t adbharadhbhar mu bheil
easeasan gam ubag man so. RinRinneadh so
agus chan fhacfhacas riariamh tuille i. Bha
Bha e na chleacchleachadh -/6 no 1/- a thilgthilgeil
san lic gu ceanceannachd a chlaichlaidh.

The cladh at Cill mhicheil used to
be locked and only those who went to their
duties were admitted. The horsehorses of the
gentry were inside.

The 3 sons of Hallan RiRigh Lochlan were sent
out of the country for murder. One was
buried at Hallan – an Cill Mhìcheil
& at Cill aulay one was Hallan
ruadh mac RiRigh LLochlainn Auladh ruaruaidh mac
RiRigh LLochlainn & Micheal ruaruadh mac RiRigh LLochlainn
The people were fighting & quarellingquarrelling
about the best place at Cladh Hough.

The Earrasaid was simply a blank-
et taken up fr.from the bed and fastened with
a crios. The larger end was down there
the smaller end was taken up over the
shoulder & down over the breast. A silver
brooch was fastened in the breast & a
dealg fiontrain down at the waist.
The blanket amply closed & covered
the whole body. The blankets was were finely
made with scarlet borders. Every
housewife tried to excel in her blankets.
The Breid was a ydyard of fine linen
with 3 banns on the shoulder & back.
There was no sewing upon it.

An Leumaire-ruaLeumaire-ruadh at Holm
below Ru-thoirinnisRubha-thoirinnis. Then here the womwoman
was left. There is a deep narrow channel
which a persperson might leap. The place
is full of limpets. The two women were
two sweethearts the man had. He marmarried
one & left the other & the marmarried one reremained
on the rock till the first bhoinne
lionailionaidh & theretherefore was unable to leave
The man, marmarried, the young girl & lived with
her till one day when she was milkgmilking
the cows she was singsinging this song
He over heard her & underunderstood how his first wife was
lost. He left his herwife & never retdreturned.
The woman sat on the top of the rock
and comp.composed the song while the other
sat opp.opposite her & learnt it from her.

div.p:
This was a truthful song. The two wo.women
& the man belonged to IocarIochdar & both the man had been
courting. He marmarried one & the other resolved upon re
venge.

Righ Duncan MacLellan
Carnan (Mason, crofter) Friday
298 May 1869.

Righ Lochlans two childchildren were
out playing one day – Mor agus Aula
Dearg – They went down to a stream
below their fathfather's house and seegseeing
a small coit – "coit an da raimh"
& the day being fine they went into it
and went paddling about. The wind
drove them abou out and a drift
till they landlanded at Amhunn Hough
They grew up Mor died & was buriburied
at Hough. Her bro.brother died & was burburied at
Cill Aulai.Amhlaidh. Ri.Righ L.Lochlainn sent messengers
over all Europe to see if his children
could be traced. Some peoppeople who
seen them in the coit told him
they had seen them. The man who
came here retdreturned & told the King they
were after dying here. Then the
King knowgknowing that this was a sav.savage
savage place
sent word to the Pope to send a naomh
cle'achcleireach, manach, or cardinal to
gu beannachabeannachadh nan cladh un
gun d fhuair e mach gur h e
aite fiadhaich gun bhean.bheannachadh gun
choisrigeadh sam bibith a bh-ann
and that he would pay him a large
sum of money. The Pope sent
Naomh-Blianan. He took with
him as usual a sackful of uir na
RoimhRoimh. He first came to Hough & put
a spadeful there & conseconsecrated it. The meanmeaning
of the name is Tunga Moire. Torrs
mor. He then came to where Suladeag
was burburied & when he came in sight of the
Knoll he took of his ceannadach &
blessed the cladh & calldcalled it Cillaul
aiCill Amhlaidh. For 200 ysyards south of Cill aulaiCill Amhlaidh whiwhich
the saint began blessgblessing the place the plplace
is calldcalled BeannachaBeannachadh Bhlianain.
Two P spadefuls of uir na Roimh
were put here – one more than in of
cladh in the Long IslIsle Naomh
Bhrianain went there & conse.consecrated all
the other cladhs in whole LLong Is.Isle Carnish
among others. But Cill aulay
has the honour above all others
of having one spadeful of the earth
of Rome more than any other cladh
in the L.Long Isle.

div.p:
Said to have been comp.composed by Mairi ninnighean
Alastair RuaiRuaidh. She lived in ClanranadClanranald
house for long years. ClanClanranald brotbrought her to
Uist Bean unmarunmarried He marmarried her on
guala Ruaiveal after having landlanded
on Fui'e bheag Uisgeva. He would
not bring her to his pelios unmar.unmarried &
he made the priest marry them
in the Carras (Lent) He propromised the pripriest
that he would give him the head of
his table as long as he lived if the other
priest went to dispose of him for per.permitting
a marriage in to Lent. The priest
was depdeplored but ClanClanranald refused to impleimplement
his brobrother. The ppriest then made him a guiguidhe
Moran sliocsliochd us beagan gliocais
He got this & his childchildren were sent out
among the ten.tenantry as fools.

This was on guala deadeas na beinne
close to leabaleabaidh a PhrionsaPhrionnsa

div.p:
A carlin who had much money hidden
she was in last dottage the 3 sons feared
they would never find out where she hid the
money for she was keeping it for her next husbhusband.
So they adopted the plan of making an
effegy of lover. They brotbrought her trothrough the door and BBook 2 ppage TransTranscribed June 18 1869
AAlexander AArchibald CCarmichael
told her that her soon was comgcoming He
then sent for an ox to slaughter for a wedwedding
feast. She pldplaced her one foot upon the ulaiulaidh
and then they ascertained the place
of its concealment.

div.p:
An old man in Baileshear
heard this song in a bruthbruthainn in a
croccnoc fraoich while pulling heathheather.
He heard this in a warm (braiste
day. He sat down took off his bont.bonnet
& had the song when he retdreturned at night
and the whole baile gath.gathered to hear
the oran sisith. The man was Iain
mac Aonais MacAulay. Twas
heard at Croca-du-AmhainCnoca-dubh-Amhainn an
iasgaich. The Knoll was always
haunted and even to this day none
likes to pass the way. One Mary
Mac Aulay in Baileshear while
out in search of sheep to mile saw
two women coming out frfrom this si
einsithein. They had on green petticoats
with sheen of silver. One tall & one
short & both of exceedgexceeding beauty & grace
Their green dresses were like the
dewy grass. They accost.accosted her & told
her where she was gog.going – for her caig-
ean chaorach. & told her where she
would find one & then where the other.
They then told her to go on till she
would see a tall man with a white sheet
in his hand for her life not to go in his
sight. They then gave her a small
stone round stone with a hole in centre
& told her to keep it & that while she lived she
would have plenty of sheep & to give this
stone to her dautdaughter. This the woman
did & she & her desc.ddescendents have been
noted for the manner in which
their sheep have prospprospered.

She saw the tall tall man
& he was so tall that the fright.frightened her
life & she threw herself down in a
ditch & then remremainded till he went
out of sight. He looked all rd.round
and gazed upon the sky. She
made for home & lay in leabaleabaidh
bais for a long time & last recvrecovered

div.p:
Heard these fr.from her mother who had
a large number of songs & lays of grtgreat
antiquity. Her mother (Cailleach Corunna")
was throthrough the whole Peninsular
war. She was at Coruna & gave a drink of cold
water to Sir John Moore after he fell. Her fre-
quent talk about Coruna led the people to nick
name herself "Coruna" & by this name she was
knowknown in the place.

Loch Sgadavadh Isle in. Old ruins. A
water Sketch of plan with measurements place for the boat pist
at the door. Perhaps 2
or 3 hundrhundred yearyears old. The thickest
heather roots or eilteach I ever saw.
Eilean-du-morEilean-dubh-mor, a pillar abtabout 57 where
the late lord MacDonald killed his first stag
abtabout 35 ysyears ago on the waters edge. A Gall whisky
was spent. Sgadavagh an Isle low
green & flat in the take after which the
lake is named. A number of plants in
it. Isle on the take bet.between AiriAiridh na gaoithe & AiriAiridh
nan faochaag seilicheag like an eg egg in shape
LLength 50 ysyards x 20. All round this solisolid stone
shore placdplaced in order by man Isle bright
& long heathheather. AiriAiridh na gaoigaoithe. A Cromleach
a cirle of rude stone and a large stone
in centre on ground. L.Length B.Breadth On one of
the stones in cirle a natural St Andrews
cross the full length of stone – a vein of
hard trapped puinent. Other large stones
lying about several smaller crom
leacs. Recess room for a man under
a stone lying on top of other at the back
of the flag contgcontaining the cross. Curvious. Old
bones of sheep & limpets under these
stones. Corm leac within circleLLength 97 x 4½
Cross LLength 8 by one foot & 5 feet the other. Stone one
which the cross 8 ffeet x 6 ffeet. Evidently
this the remains of some old ruins.
On top still the foundation can be
Traced. On the south side a number
of ainnis the people add.

Womans choice. A woman had her hus-
band son & brother incarcerated in jail
for a heinous crime. They were to be put
to death but the woman was told that she
would get her choice released her and
was requested to name her choice –
Gheo'arGheobhar fear an coill 's gabhar mac
am broin 'son nach beir mo mhathair
mac tuille 's e mo bhrathair is docha
liom. Tis said that she got the three
released her.

ComhaltasComhdhaltas gu ceud s caidean go
fichead

div.p:
None but a MacIosaig dared visit
this Glen till this rhyme was comp.composed.
After that no objectobjection was made to any.

John MacLellan 82 a little old man
at Hacleit Creag. has the lay of the Buil
eartach & the lay of the Amadan Mor
fuller than I ever heard them before.

Air sealbh bhairneach said the old
man through the ord bhair behind his
back. This was the way to get fish and
shell fish the next day.

Flora MacDonald || her eldest ||
From Mrs Maclellan Ormacleit
12 AplApril 1870 Tuesday.
Her eldest brother Ranald was
kildkilled by a gun accaccident. He was on a visit to
MacDonald of Leargy his relation. There
were several gents.gentlemen on a visit at the time.
They were going out shootgshooting. Two were short of
guns. The host said there is one gun in the
house whoso gets it first will have it
for himself. Ranald MacDonMacDonald and
ananother gent.gentleman ran to the gun and the two
took hold & in the strug.stuggle the shot went
off and took away his scalp. and
smashed his head. This blood is seen
on the floor of the dining room at Cara.
Angus was 2 yrsyears youngyounger than Flora
as she was 2 yrsyears youngyounger than Ranald.
She was 19 when she returned frfrom EdinEdinburgh
where she had been eitheither 2 or 3 yrsyears. She
was abtabout 21 when she left with the Prince.

She left Corrodale with him and was
that night at isle Fuidheay in BenBenbecula
where they had to put in. Angus Mac
Donald Floras brother was Mrs
MacLellans grandfather. He had
10 sons & 4 daught.daughters and his wife was
only 39 when she died who was a dautdaughter of
Angus MacDonald of Balfinlay. FloraFlora's
mother was a datdaughter of the Rev Angus
MacDonald of SSouth Uist. He is on a
buried at Howmore. Rev Mr Angus Mac
DonDonald's wife was a daterdaughter of MacDonMacDonald of
Leargs. Floras yngyounger bro.brother was not born
when his fathfather died so no proprovision was made
for him, and when he gra was edu.educated by
a his maternal uncle & when he grew up
Clanranald gave him Milton. His
mother was abducted by Hew Mac
Donald of Sleat who took no notice
of Angus as he saw that he took
his prozprovision from him. One of Angus
sons who went to sea 6 ft.feet 6 in hightheight
Another bro.brother Gilbert was a ret.retired CapCaptain in
the Scots Royals – never left the one
Reg.Regiment – left upupwards of £3000 to a brobrother of
ClanrdClanranald who had a large family in
EdinEdinburgh £50 to the poor of EdinbEdinburgh £400
£600 to his sister the leatelate Mrs Mun-
ro Ibut £400 to her son Col.Colonel Munro
& £3020 to his son Angus and £20
to the poor of SSouth Uist. This good man
died in EdinbEdinburgh abtabout30 or 40 years ago. He left
£150 to MisMiss MacLellan. He is burburied in
Grey-friars EdinEdinburgh where the Clanranald
& Boisdale & ColColonel Munro are also.
Mor nieannighean Mhic AonaisAonghais was FloraFlora's
mother. Floras nephew Angus was
drowndrowned in Lochaoineart. He was sent
along with maymany otherothers frfrom here to the Amer
ican wars where he sev.served 7 yrs.years & was conconsidered the
best swordsman there. Often & often
he saved with his claiclaidheamh mor his com
panions. He retdreturned with the Major
MacDonMacDonald Aisgernish Sandy
MacDonald Boisdale was CaptCaptain DualDughall
an Drs Droma who went away
as a soldier of Fortune. Adjutant
MacDonald was captcaptain in the Militia
here. He mar.married a dautdaughter of Boisdale.
He sent out a boy to tell a boat to be ready
for him sig with out but seeseeing the boy reachdreached the boat was
awry & he had to take a boat loaded with kelp
When gggoing out a heavy storm came on
& fildfilled the deep load.loaded boat. He had on
a shot bag powder horn and full HighHighland
dress which he always wore. He got
hold of an aoroar but seeing an old man
who lived on his own farm he gave him
the oar & struck for the shore himself. He
had 3 big dogs all which were about his
arm over his back and impeding his
prog.progress. When near the shore He saw
a boat & he turned to it. There were two wo-
men in the boat and when the boat-
men attemptattempted to rescue the drowdrowning
men the women got into big stones
grasped hold of their men & would not
let them and the storm drove on
the boat & the bravest man in
SSouth Uist was lost. 2 young lads & him
were lost & 3 old men came ashore.
Sometimes 1 & 2 & 3 of dogs wldwould be on his
back. He gave the oars to the 3 old men
and left the 2 yng.young men to shift for them.themselves
Floras brobrother got Bailevanaich after he grew up.
His fathfather hadn't this.

It was Capt MacDonald Sandy RaolRaghnall Ōg who
built the first house at Nunton some
time after TotaTobhta mhòr was burnt in 1715 –
the night of SherrffmuirSherriffmuir Allan was
the ClanranadClanranald who was killed there.
He is said to have had a sian put on by
his muime was never bled in battle
before althoalthough oftoften there. A man whom he sent
out of the country for some misdeed shot
him with a sixpence. It was he who said
{cluich BuileBuille an diugh is gul a marmaireach
Bu duine an de e. said his daltdalta.
Curious Flora MacDonald's father
was a handsome young man
& aleg.allegedly about this Allan as a compcompanion.
The dowager Lady ClanClanranald fell in
love with him and was ga thoirt
a mach a dheoin no dh ainaindeoin.
RaolRaghnall mac AonaisAonghais oig told
Allan that he knew not what to do
that his mother was had a design
upon him! Never you mind said
Allan I'll make a plan Ill lock
you up in the toll dudubh and pretend
that I am going to send you out of the
country but youll not be displdispleased
This he did. Lady ClanClanranald was not see-
ing RaolRaghnall so she was asking severseveral perspersons
His son heard her & askdasked her what
she was saysaying. I have him in charge
till I send him out over sàl. Why
that? Because he is doing what
I don't approve of. Leig a mach
dhomhsa RaolRaghnall mac AonAonghais oig
Allain mhic RaoilRaghnaill oidhre
no gheogheobh mise athar eile dhuit.
A dhroch bhean chan eil fios
fhin nach bu shuarach mi
ort. and he let him out and he had
to marry her. She bore him one
dat.daughter who died after having been
several years in school in
Glasg.Glasgow. This was n Mor Og
nieannighean mhic Leoid 'Ga dona
Mor mhor seach measa
Mh Mor Og" # 13 AplApril 1870.

EEilean Bheagram was built by Allan mac
Iain mhic Iain MhuideartichMhuideartaich
ic Alastair. He was a brother to ClanClanranald.
He at first began building at Iollam a
Or chaisteal at Fadhail Hough
which he abandoned & then built Castle
Bheagram. Ranald Mac Allain
this mans son lived in Castle Bhuiri
John mac Eachain says that it was
Eifirig ni Choinnich that built CastCastle
Bhuiri. He says Flora MacDonald
sailed with the Prince with the Prince from
Roisinnis

Curious on Saturday 20 May 1870 saw
on the farm of Amhor N.North Uist a sheep up to the
middle in the water of a lakelet gathering a few
stray blades of grass that were growing in the clear
water. Never saw such before.

Dunvegan Castle off Keallun 24 May 701870
Tempull Mhicheil fine view from it.
No chapel in Rona contracontrary to Martin's. So this must
be the chapel he means. He speaks of but one
chapel from which we may infer that the othother
chapel whose site & that of the burying ground
are pointpointed out was not in existexistence whennear he wrote
nearly 200 ago. 2 sailors are said to be buried
in S.Saint M.Michael's Martin calls it the Lowlanders
chapels Twas in connxconnexion with the church
of the whole Holy Trinity Cairinish of which
tradition says Anne MacRuary was
supersuperindenent and which ancient records say
she made over to the monks of Inchaffary.

St. Donans house in Eilean Donain
LLength 50 x 26 feet. with several surrounding ruins
Length of Isle 70 ydsyards. BBreadth 50 yards. This isle
is about 25 ydsyards from the next isle which is abtabout
2545 50 ydsyards from CladdhCladh Donain. Cladh Donain
is a peninsula with a no.number of ruins and that
of a chapel & altar and the font in a herds
house at Milton & used as a crotag. IslIsle
Donain is a small grengreen fertile isle field
of nettles & vitarus Alba. St Donan is said to hve
lived here & the the large ruin is called 'Taigh-
Dhonnain'. Graves and caibeil are in the
Peninsula of cleadhcladh DonDonain. Near by is the hamlet
of Kildonain the ruins of many houses frfrom which
the people were ousted abt.about 40 yrsyears ago. Beautiful
land now a sheep track. AbtAbout 20 tenants
Flora MacDonald is said to have lived here
left her husband fr.from jealousy.
Alain ChisburghChinsburgh came to Lochaoineart and
was so infirm with rheumatism & flesh & age
that he had to be carried upon a cra-leaba to Bornish
where he remained that night and proceeded next day
to Kildonan to Flora's house. How long they remained

Ann Nic Rury Malaclett NNorth Uist 4 July
1870 Monday

Cho luath 's a dh-fhag uthu mo sheal.shealladh
Bha thu cal s cha b e 'n t-am
Nuair bhios am bodach 'sa cholaich
S e gu'n leon 's e gu'n nearstneart
Bi a chlann anns a bhīgeil
Gun deilbh eir rud ac
S eir nuair thuigeas tu an doruin
S ga boil le d l shroin tha uthu nan glaic.

div.p: Le Cairistiona Ciadna

Oisein eibhineibhinn a mhic Fhinn
A Laoich fhaoilidh bu mhor pris
Innis dhomhs sgeul eir Conal
DonulDomhnull CurriCurraidh SSouth Lochboisdale
whom see –

lg.l: Togamsadh (Togai mis?) an teine an diugh
An lathair aillean naomha neamh
An lathair Ghabriel is aisde cruth
An lathair Mhicheil namnam milte sgeimh -
Gun ghnu, gun tnu gun fharmad,
Gun ghoimh, gu'n fheirmh ri fear no te ro'mh neach fon ghrein
Ach naomh Mhac De bhi'm thearmad.
A Dhe fadaifadaidh fein nam chridhe steach
Aitheal ghraighraidh; do'm choimharsnach
Do'm naimhnaimhdean, do'm dhaimh do'm chairdean
Do'n t-saoi don daoi don traille

l.add: O! A Mhic na Moire mhinghile

lg.l: Do'n te (M?) is is ilse crannachar
A chon an Ainm is airde.

div.p:
"Bu mhath an t saighdiaracsaigheadaireachd mar
bhibhith na blair"

Aithealag = eibhleag = small peat fire.
Oar.

lg.l: He prayeth best who loveth best
All things both great and small
For the dear God who loveth us
He made and loveth all – Coleridge
Is fhada bh'uambhuam fhin bonn Beinneadara
Is fhada gun teagabh uam Bealach a mhorghain
Cul BBeinn eadara bonn BBeinn eadara
Cul BBeinneadara, bonn BBeinn eadara
'Us a mhorghain.
Gheobhar fear an coill
Gheobhar mac am broinn
'S nar nach beir mo mhathair tuillidh
S e mo bhrathirbrathair is docha leam.
